text: The thing about logs is that they are all differ solely by a constant factor _k_ (similar to the difference between miles and kilometres). So, most of the time, it doesn't matter if all you're saying is that `g(n) ~ n log n` or something similar. However, you do need to be clear about the differences in some situations, especially when we talk about the exact number of operations required by, say, merge sort.
In particular, if you're drawing a log-log graph and measuring the slope to get the exponent of _n_, it makes no difference provided of course that you use the same logs in both axes :wink:

Instead of plotting a graph, I took multiple values for every value of n and took mean of that to remove the effect of randomness. Then compared the result with mathematical value of f(n) of same. A little like in previous the random walk problem. I hope thats is also ok as I have already submitted :thinking_face:.
